elements.content: A water stable and highly hydrophilic porous coordination polymer based on viologen-carboxylate type ligand, the 4,4′-bipyridinium,1,1-bis­(3-carboxyphenyl) (pc2), is obtained by the solvothermal method: [Cd3(pc2) (BTC)2(H2O)2]·6H2O ([1(H2O)2]·6H2O; BTC3– = 1,3,5-carboxybenzene). Its crystal structure and the ones of two partially dehydrated phases have been determined, allowing insight into the mechanism of water adsorption/desorption of this PCP material. It is shown that the dehydrated compound [1] first adsorbs two water molecules which fill the pores, leading to [1]·2H2O. On the other hand, the partial dehydration of the as-synthesized compound leads to the intermediate phase [1(H2O)]·3H2O in which one H2O molecule is bound to Cd2+ ions of trinuclear building units, and three others are localized in the pores. The structural analysis also reveals that the pyridinium N+ Lewis sites, which interact with water molecules in [1(H2O)2]·6H2O, interact with carboxylate groups after structural reorganization in [1]·2H2O. The water adsorption isotherm clearly shows that the dehydrated compound is highly hydrophilic and adsorbs water in three steps: first and second at P/P S < 0.01 and third at P/P S ∼ 0.1 with the overall water adsorption reaching 0.13 g H2O/g. This material is also able to reversibly adsorb ammonia (up to 0.3 g/g or 17.6 mmol/g).

elements.content: In the field of porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), the reactivity of such materials toward water is of great importance. For many applications at the industrial level, such as chemical sensors, gas storage, and catalysis, the stability of materials toward water is crucial. Unfortunately, many PCPs are moisture sensitive, especially those based on carboxylate ligands and divalent metal cations such as the well-known MOF-5 or HKUST PCPs. Several strategies have been developed to improve the water stability, by using imidazolate ligands instead of carboxylate ones (ZIFs PCPs as ZIF-8), or by using cations with high valence number as Zr4+ (Zr-PCPs as UiO66). On the other hand, the adsorption of a large amount of water or the adsorption at very low pressure in water stable PCPs is a current hot topic because of potential applications in heat pumps, adsorbent-based chillers, proton conductors, or production and delivery of drinking water.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the field of porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), the reactivity of such materials toward water is of great importance. For many applications at the industrial level, such as chemical sensors, gas storage, and catalysis, the stability of materials toward water is crucial. Unfortunately, many PCPs are moisture sensitive, especially those based on carboxylate ligands and divalent metal cations such as the well-known MOF-5 or HKUST PCPs. Several strategies have been developed to improve the water stability, by using imidazolate ligands instead of carboxylate ones (ZIFs PCPs as ZIF-8), or by using cations with high valence number as Zr4+ (Zr-PCPs as UiO66). On the other hand, the adsorption of a large amount of water or the adsorption at very low pressure in water stable PCPs is a current hot topic because of potential applications in heat pumps, adsorbent-based chillers, proton conductors, or production and delivery of drinking water.

elements.content: The incorporation of viologen-carboxylate ligands in the framework of PCPs has been considered quite recently. Such a ligand is based on bipyridinium (viologen) units covalently linked to groups bearing carboxylate functions. Viologen is a well-known electron acceptor unit able to interact with electron donor entities. Such donor–acceptor interaction often results in colored solids due to the presence of a charge transfer band in the visible region, or due to a broad band covering all the visible region, typical of the radical cation, in the case of an electron transfer from a strong electron donor to the viologen. Besides its redox property, the bipyridinium unit which is cationic can also be considered a Lewis acid. Such sites in PCPs are mainly metal open sites, which are created when solvent molecules bound to metal ions are removed during the activation process. PCPs based on viologen-carboxylate ligands are expected to be hydrophilic. And in fact, water molecules can strongly interact with nitrogen sites of pyridinium cycles with contact distances as short as 3.00 Å as shown in the structure of the hydrated zwiterrionic compounds (pc1)·2H2O (pc1 = 1,1-bis­(4-carboxyphenyl)-4,4′-bipyridinium). On the other hand the cationic nature of viologen-carboxylate ligands is a challenge in the synthesis of PCPs materials. Since bipyridinium units have strong abilities to interact with carboxylate groups of neighboring ligands in the solid state, dense coordination polymers are obtained in most cases, however often exhibiting interesting photochromic properties due to electron transfer from CO2 – groups to viologen units. While some anionic viologen-carboxylate linkers have been used, most such linkers are zwitterionic. In are shown the chemical structures of some of them, the asymmetrical ones consisting of one pyridyl unit on one side and one carboxylate function on the other side (hpc1, hpc1′, hpc2), and the symmetrical ones (pc1, pc1′, pc2). The latter based on diquaternized bipyridinium units are expected to have better electron-acceptor behavior than the former. Finally, we can notice that the number of PCPs based on such viologen-carboxylate ligands has increased these past five years, particularly those based on hpc1, pc1, and pc1′.

elements.content: Due to the similar characteristics of both NH3 and H2O molecules, the network of hydrophilic PCPs is particularly well suited to strongly interact with NH3. Ammonia is one of the most toxic gases among those produced and is used on a large scale. If materials such as zeolites or activated carbons are known to exhibit good adsorption capacities, however, the progressive desorption over time remains a challenging issue. Thus, PCPs materials have appeared as potential candidates for ammonia storage. Recently, we reported on a viologen-carboxylate PCP exhibiting high ammonia uptake. However, in this material as in most of the tested PCPs, the networks collapse upon NH3 adsorption as a result of metal-NH3 coordination.
elements.clean_text: Due to the similar characteristics of both NH3 and H2O molecules, the network of hydrophilic PCPs is particularly well suited to strongly interact with NH3. Ammonia is one of the most toxic gases among those produced and is used on a large scale. If materials such as zeolites or activated carbons are known to exhibit good adsorption capacities, however, the progressive desorption over time remains a challenging issue. Thus, PCPs materials have appeared as potential candidates for ammonia storage. Recently, we reported on a viologen-carboxylate PCP exhibiting high ammonia uptake. However, in this material as in most of the tested PCPs, the networks collapse upon NH3 adsorption as a result of metal-NH3 coordination.

elements.content: Here, we report on the synthesis and adsorption properties of a water stable 3D PCP based on the pc2 viologen-caboxylate ligand (pc2 = 4,4′-bipyridinium-1,1-bis­(3-carboxyphenyl), ), [Cd3(pc2) (BTC)2(H2O)2]·6H2O ([1(H2O)2]·6H2O) (BTC3– = 1,3,5-carboxy-benzene). Its crystal structure, as well as that of two partially dehydrated phases [1(H2O)]·3H2O and [1]·2H2O, has been determined allowing a detailed description of the structural transitions provoked by water desorption and adsorption processes. We show that a high resolution water adsorption isotherm confirms this three-step adsorption process. It clearly shows the highly hydrophilic nature of the compound: 50% of water molecules being adsorbed at P/P S < 0.01, which can be related to the presence of Lewis acid sites in the structure (metal open sites and pyridinium cycles). In addition, the prepared PCP possesses high capacity toward NH3 attaining the loading of 0.3 g/g (17.6 mmol/g) at 930 hPa. Despite the collapse of the crystalline structure after NH3 adsorption, the solid capacity for ammonia is restored after regeneration.

Its crystal structure, as well as that of two partially dehydrated phases [1(H2O)]⋅3H2O and [1]⋅2H2O, has been determined allowing a detailed description of the structural transitions provoked by water desorption and adsorption processes. We show that a high resolution water adsorption isotherm confirms this three-step adsorption process. It clearly shows the highly hydrophilic nature of the compound: 50% of water molecules being adsorbed at P/P S < 0.01, which can be related to the presence of Lewis acid sites in the structure (metal open sites and pyridinium cycles). Despite the collapse of the crystalline structure after NH3 adsorption, the solid capacity for ammonia is restored after regeneration.

elements.content: All starting materials were of analytical grade and obtained from commercial sources without further purifications. 4,4′-Bipyridinium-1,1-bis­(3-carboxyphenyl) dichloride dihydrate ((H2pc2)­Cl2·2H2O) ligand was synthesized according to the literature (SI). Thermogravimetric analyses were performed using a TGA-2050 TA Instruments Systems from room temperature to 1000 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under nitrogen flow. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) analyses were measured at room temperature on a D8 Bruker diffractometer (Cu Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å) equipped with a linear Vantec superspeed detector.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All starting materials were of analytical grade and obtained from commercial sources without further purifications. 4,4'-Bipyridinium-1,1-bis(3-carboxyphenyl) dichloride dihydrate ((H2pc2)Cl2⋅2H2O) ligand was synthesized according to the literature (SI). Thermogravimetric analyses were performed using a TGA-2050 TA Instruments Systems from room temperature to 1000 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under nitrogen flow. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) analyses were measured at room temperature on a D8 Bruker diffractometer (Cu Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å) equipped with a linear Vantec superspeed detector.

elements.content: A mixture of (H2pc2)­Cl2·2H2O (25.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), Cd­(ClO4)2 hydrate (62.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), DMF (2 mL), and H2O (2 mL) was slowly heated to 105 °C at a rate of 10 °C/h for 48 h in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. After the mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/h, suitable crystals for X-ray analyses were collected, washed with fresh DMF, and air-dried. [Cd3(pc2) (BTC)2(H2O)2]·6H2O 60% yield based on (H2pc2)­Cl2·2H2O. Anal. Calc. for Cd3C42H38O24N2 (1291.97): C, 39.05%; H, 2.94%; N, 2.17%. Found: C, 39.15%; H, 2.87%; N, 2.18%.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Cd3(pc2) (BTC)2(H2O)2]⋅6H2O

A mixture of (H2pc2)Cl2⋅2H2O (25.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), Cd(ClO4)2 hydrate (62.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), DMF (2 mL), and H2O (2 mL) was slowly heated to 105 °C at a rate of 10 °C/h for 48 h in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. After the mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/h, suitable crystals for X-ray analyses were collected, washed with fresh DMF, and air-dried. [Cd3(pc2) (BTC)2(H2O)2]⋅6H2O 60% yield based on (H2pc2)Cl2⋅2H2O. Anal. Calc. for Cd3C42H38O24N2 (1291.97): C, 39.05%; H, 2.94%; N, 2.17%. Found: C, 39.15%; H, 2.87%; N, 2.18%.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction data were collected on an Agilent Supernova with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Data were collected at 150 K from selected single crystals of [1(H2O)2]·6H2O, [1(H2O)]·3H2O, and [1]·2H2O under nitrogen atmosphere. Crystals of the two partially hydrated phases were obtained by a slow heating of as-synthesized crystals. This step has involved breaking crystals into many fragments. After several attempts, we could successfully collect data using very small crystals, which further allowed the full determination of crystal structures. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by full-matrix least-squares method with anisotropic approximation for all non-hydrogen atoms, using the SHELX97 package. For [1(H2O)2]·6H2O, three independent water molecules were located in cavities, while another independent molecule is coordinated to the inorganic node, leading to a total of 8 water molecules per formula unit, in good accordance with the TGA experiment and water adsorption isotherm. For [1(H2O)]·3H2O whose unit cell is twice greater than the one of [1(H2O)2]·6H2O, the asymmetric unit includes three Cd2+ (forming the trimeric unit), one H2O molecule bound to one Cd2+, and three others in the cavities. For [1]·2H2O, a centrosymmetrical trimeric unit is found (two independent Cd2+) as in [1(H2O)2]·6H2O, the two water molecules per formula unit (one independent molecule) being found in cavities. All non-H2O hydrogen atoms were treated with a riding model. Absorption was corrected by the program SADABS. summarizes the crystallographic data for all three structures. A complete list of crystallographic data, along with the atomic coordinates, the anisotropic displacement parameters, and bond distances and angles for each compound, is given as CIF files (CCDC numbers 1534001, 1534483, 1534485 for [1(H2O)2]·6H2O, [1(H2O)]·3H2O, [1]·2H2O, respectively).
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

X-ray diffraction data were collected on an Agilent Supernova with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Data were collected at 150 K from selected single crystals of [1(H2O)2]⋅6H2O, [1(H2O)]⋅3H2O, and [1]⋅2H2O under nitrogen atmosphere. Crystals of the two partially hydrated phases were obtained by a slow heating of as-synthesized crystals. This step has involved breaking crystals into many fragments. After several attempts, we could successfully collect data using very small crystals, which further allowed the full determination of crystal structures. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by full-matrix least-squares method with anisotropic approximation for all non-hydrogen atoms, using the SHELX97 package. For [1(H2O)2]⋅6H2O, three independent water molecules were located in cavities, while another independent molecule is coordinated to the inorganic node, leading to a total of 8 water molecules per formula unit, in good accordance with the TGA experiment and water adsorption isotherm. For [1(H2O)]⋅3H2O whose unit cell is twice greater than the one of [1(H2O)2]⋅6H2O, the asymmetric unit includes three Cd2+ (forming the trimeric unit), one H2O molecule bound to one Cd2+, and three others in the cavities. For [1]⋅2H2O, a centrosymmetrical trimeric unit is found (two independent Cd2+) as in [1(H2O)2]⋅6H2O, the two water molecules per formula unit (one independent molecule) being found in cavities. All non-H2O hydrogen atoms were treated with a riding model. Absorption was corrected by the program SADABS.  summarizes the crystallographic data for all three structures. A complete list of crystallographic data, along with the atomic coordinates, the anisotropic displacement parameters, and bond distances and angles for each compound, is given as CIF files (CCDC numbers 1534001, 1534483, 1534485 for [1(H2O)2]⋅6H2O, [1(H2O)]⋅3H2O, [1]⋅2H2O, respectively).

Adsorption and desorption isotherms of CH3OH, H2O, and NH3 on [1] were recorded at 298 K by gravimetry using a home-built McBain-type thermobalance. Before measurements the samples (ca. 15 mg) were outgassed at 423 K under vacuum (10–6 h Pa) for 15 h. The detailed description of the experimental procedure can be found elsewhere. The estimated experimental error on the adsorbed amount was about 1 mg/g. The accuracy of the pressure measurement was 1%, and the temperature was maintained within 1 K. The in situ XPRD of the sample exposed to NH3 was recorded using the capillary attached to the balance and sealed off after exposure to the gas (see ref for details).
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Measurements

Adsorption and desorption isotherms of CH3OH, H2O, and NH3 on [1] were recorded at 298 K by gravimetry using a home-built McBain-type thermobalance. Before measurements the samples (ca. 15 mg) were outgassed at 423 K under vacuum (10-6 h Pa) for 15 h. The detailed description of the experimental procedure can be found elsewhere. The estimated experimental error on the adsorbed amount was about 1 mg/g. The accuracy of the pressure measurement was 1%, and the temperature was maintained within 1 K. The in situ XPRD of the sample exposed to NH3 was recorded using the capillary attached to the balance and sealed off after exposure to the gas (see ref  for details).

elements.content: The solvothermal reaction of (H2pc2)­Cl2 2H2O, cadmium perchlorate, and H3BTC led to the pure phase of a new viologen-carboxylate PCP whose formulation, first revealed from the crystal structure determination, is [Cd3(pc2) (BTC)2(H2O)2]·6H2O named [1(H2O)2]·6H2O. The thermogravimetric analysis first confirms the amount of 8 water molecules per formulation unit as the weight loss of 11.24% corresponds to the theoretical one of 11.15%. It also shows that the dehydrated compound is stable up to 350 °C, and that the water weight loss occurs in two consecutive equivalent steps of 5.65% and 5.59%, which can be assigned to the departure of 4 first water molecules following by the departure of the 4 others (). The measurement of XRPD patterns at different temperatures (thermodiffractometry) under N2 atmosphere which have been carried out in the RT–145 °C range (RT: room temperature, Figure S2) clearly shows two main phase transformations: a first change in the peak positions occurs at 35 °C giving a partially dehydrated phase which is stable up to 65 °C, while the second phase transition occurs at 85 °C giving the expected fully dehydrated phase, in accordance with the TGA analysis. We also notice another change of several peak positions at 115 °C revealing a slight change of unit cell parameters of the dehydrated phase.

Results and Discussion

Thermal Behavior and Crystal Structures

The solvothermal reaction of (H2pc2)Cl2 2H2O, cadmium perchlorate, and H3BTC led to the pure phase of a new viologen-carboxylate PCP whose formulation, first revealed from the crystal structure determination, is [Cd3(pc2) (BTC)2(H2O)2]⋅6H2O named [1(H2O)2]⋅6H2O. The thermogravimetric analysis first confirms the amount of 8 water molecules per formulation unit as the weight loss of 11.24% corresponds to the theoretical one of 11.15%. It also shows that the dehydrated compound is stable up to 350 °C, and that the water weight loss occurs in two consecutive equivalent steps of 5.65% and 5.59%, which can be assigned to the departure of 4 first water molecules following by the departure of the 4 others (). The measurement of XRPD patterns at different temperatures (thermodiffractometry) under N2 atmosphere which have been carried out in the RT-145 °C range (RT: room temperature, Figure S2) clearly shows two main phase transformations: a first change in the peak positions occurs at 35 °C giving a partially dehydrated phase which is stable up to 65 °C, while the second phase transition occurs at 85 °C giving the expected fully dehydrated phase, in accordance with the TGA analysis. We also notice another change of several peak positions at 115 °C revealing a slight change of unit cell parameters of the dehydrated phase.

elements.content: Taking into account these results, we have very slowly heated single crystals of [1(H2O)2]·6H2O up to 65 °C and up to 110 °C to see if single-crystal-to-single crystal transitions could occur. The heated crystals were taken out of the oven and were immediately put into some drops of oil. While we observed that breakage of crystals has occurred during the heating process, suitable crystals could be selected for X-ray analysis (N2 atmosphere at 150 K). From the crystal structure determination, their formulations were found to be [1(H2O)]·3H2O for the partially dehydrated compound which is in good accordance with the expected departure of 4 water molecules, and [1]·2H2O for the crystal heated at 110 °C. The unexpected presence of two water molecules per formula unit can be explained by the very hydrophilic nature of [1] (water adsorption for very low water pressure, P/P S ≈ 0.001) which has been able to take up some water molecules from the air (during the transfer of crystals from oven to oil) or from oil. shows a comparison between the theoretical XRPD patterns obtained from the crystal structure data collected at 150 K and the experimental XRPD patterns collected under N2 atmosphere of [1(H2O)2]·6H2O at room temperature, at 65 °C, and at room temperature after heating at 145 °C. As expected, the experimental and theoretical patterns of [1(H2O)2]·6H2O fit well (, down). Interestingly the experimental pattern of the fully dehydrated phase [1] fit well with the theoretical one of [1]·2H2O showing that the adsorption of the two first water molecules does not involve a significant structural change. For the sample heated at 65 °C, the pattern does not fit perfectly with the theoretical one of [1(H2O)]·3H2O, some lines being slightly shifted one from the other. This may be explained by the different temperatures of data collection, −123 °C for the single crystal unit cell and 65 °C for the experimental XRPD pattern.

elements.content: The three-dimensional (3D) crystal structure of [1(H2O)2]·6H2O is built up from trimeric inorganic units linked together through the BTC3– and pc2 ligands. The centrosymmetrical trimeric unit consists of two kinds of polyhedron (). The first independent cadmium atom (Cd2) which is located on a symmetry center adopts a common octahedral geometry based on four oxygen atoms of bridging carboxylate groups and two oxygen atoms of two carboxylate groups shared with neighboring polyhedra. The second independent cadmium atom (Cd1) which lies on a general position is surrounded by seven oxygen atoms, four from bridging carboxylate groups, two from another carboxylate group, and one from a water molecule. The formulation of the resulting centrosymmetrical unit is [Cd3(CO2)8(H2O)2], the eight carboxylate groups belonging to 6 BTC3– and two pc2 ligands (). The overall structure results from the connection of the inorganic nodes by both pc2 and BTC3– ligands. Each pc2 molecule is shared by two trimeric units (roughly along the a direction when the structure is viewed along c, ) while each BTC3– ligand is shared by three inorganic units, leading to a 3D network whose formulation is [Cd3(pc2)2/2(BTC)6/3(H2O)2] ([Cd3(pc2) (BTC)3(H2O)2]). The 3D network, which is porous, includes six guest water molecules per formula unit in cavities of the structure. The porosity has been estimated to 10% according to calculations using the Squeeze routine of Platon when guest water molecules are removed (b).

elements.content: Upon dehydration of [1(H2O)2]·6H2O, as already shown by powder diffractometry, two consecutive structural changes occur. As expected from TGA experiment, the crystal structure of the partially dehydrated phase reveals that [1(H2O)2]·6H2O lost half the water molecules per formula unit during the first desorption step. However, while it was expected that all four water molecules were guest molecules contained in pores, it appears that only three such molecules and one water molecule of the trimeric unit were desorbed, leading to the [1(H2O)]·3H2O phase. Thus, the trimeric unit whose formulation is [Cd3(CO2)8(H2O)] becomes asymmetrical in [1(H2O)]·3H2O, and consisting of three independent cadmium atoms with the water molecule linked to one external cadmium (). We already indicated that the X-ray study had revealed that single crystals heated over 100 °C unexpectedly contained two water molecules per formula unit leading to the [1]·2H2O phase. It must be noted that the two partially dehydrated phases (and certainly the fully dehydrated phase as shown by XRPD) have a similar unit cell volume (V = 3960/2 = 1980 Å3 for [1(H2O)]·3H2O and V = 2020 Å3 for [1]·2H2O phase; for a general view of both structures see Figures S4–5), which is only 9% less than the volume of [1(H2O)2]·6H2O (2180 Å3). In fact, the squeeze routine of Platon using the structure of [1]·2H2O for which water molecules have been removed shows that the crystal structure of the desorbed phase is still porous (porosity of 7%). This may explain the uptake at very low P/P° of the two first water molecules in this hydrophilic PCP that interact quite strongly with H atoms of the bipyridinium cores (Figure S6). If the structural breathing effect is not impressive along with these phase transitions, the interesting feature is the structural reorganization upon dehydration in order to satisfy the electron acceptor character of the viologen unit. In [1(H2O)2]·6H2O, the pyridinium cycle of the symmetrical pc2 ligand interact at the N+ site with one water molecule bound to Cd1 (O9) and one guest water molecule (O12, ). In [1]·2H2O, a rotation of the planar viologen core has occurred, the dihedral angle between the pyridinium cycle and the phenyl cycle going from 43.1° in [1(H2O)2]·6H2O to 82.4° in [1]·2H2O. As a consequence, the pyridinium unit at the N+ site is now interacting from each side with two oxygen atoms (O5 and O3) of carboxylate groups ().

elements.content: The presence of permanent porosity in fully dehydrated [1] is confirmed by the adsorption of methanol at 298 K (Figure S7). The shape of the isotherm is characteristic of a microporous solid and the maximum adsorbed amount of methanol (0.09 g/g) corresponds to pore volume of 0.11 cm3/g. The isotherm of water adsorption on dehydrated [1] compound is presented in . The saturation uptake is close to eight molecules of water per formula unit in accordance with TGA and structure determination, corresponding to an adsorption of 0.13 g.g–1. The step in the isotherm occurring at four H2O molecules is attributed to the formation of the intermediate phase containing this number of water molecules. This step in the adsorption isotherm and a slight hysteresis are indicative of a structural rearrangement during the transition between the phase containing four H2O molecules and the fully hydrated one. Another important feature of the isotherm is a strong adsorption at a very low water pressure: the solid adsorbs a half the water below 0.01 of saturated water pressure, and nearly all the water molecules at P/P S = 0.1. Such behavior reveals a strong hydrophilic character of [1] in comparison with most of the known MOFs as reported in two recent reviews on water adsorption in MOFs. Finally, the log scale drawing of the water adsorption isotherm (, right) allows one to distinguish for the first adsorption step (four water molecules) two substeps of two water molecules each, the first substep corresponding to extremely low water pressure (P/P S < 0.001). It is also worth noting that the crystal structure of the phase we expected to be fully dehydrated has revealed the presence of two water molecules per formula unit. In addition to its strong hydrophilic character, [1] shows a remarkable stability toward water. It preserves a constant water capacity in multiple cycles of water adsorption (Figure S8). Also, its structure is fully preserved after immersion in liquid water as attested by XRPD (Figure S3).

CH3OH, H2O, and NH3 Adsorption Measurements

The presence of permanent porosity in fully dehydrated [1] is confirmed by the adsorption of methanol at 298 K (Figure S7). The shape of the isotherm is characteristic of a microporous solid and the maximum adsorbed amount of methanol (0.09 g/g) corresponds to pore volume of 0.11 cm3/g. The isotherm of water adsorption on dehydrated [1] compound is presented in . The step in the isotherm occurring at four H2O molecules is attributed to the formation of the intermediate phase containing this number of water molecules. This step in the adsorption isotherm and a slight hysteresis are indicative of a structural rearrangement during the transition between the phase containing four H2O molecules and the fully hydrated one. Another important feature of the isotherm is a strong adsorption at a very low water pressure: the solid adsorbs a half the water below 0.01 of saturated water pressure, and nearly all the water molecules at P/P S = 0.1. Such behavior reveals a strong hydrophilic character of [1] in comparison with most of the known MOFs as reported in two recent reviews on water adsorption in MOFs. Finally, the log scale drawing of the water adsorption isotherm (, right) allows one to distinguish for the first adsorption step (four water molecules) two substeps of two water molecules each, the first substep corresponding to extremely low water pressure (P/P S < 0.001). elements.content: [1] adsorbs a significant amount of ammonia attaining 0.3 g/g or 17.6 mmol/g at 930 hPa (a). This important uptake is due to chemisorption of NH3 which interacts with Cd2+ cations and forms the [Cd­(NH3)6]2+ complex similarly to another Cd-based PCP described in our previous work. Giving Cd content in the anhydrous material (2.6 mmol/g), this adsorption mechanism could provide the capacity of 15.6 mmol­(NH3)/g. Such chemisorption should naturally result in degradation of the crystalline structure of the material, which indeed happens in [1] saturated with ammonia as confirmed by in situ XRPD (c). It should be noted, however, that degassing the sample at 298 K results in the appearance of a peak at ∼9.5° in the diffraction pattern indicative of the existence of a partial crystalline order in the degassed sample. Moreover, upon contact with air the peak shifts to ∼9.2° reflecting the swelling of the partially ordered structure upon insertion of water molecules. Even if the attribution of this peak to any crystalline plane is impossible, this behavior is similar to that of the (110) peak located at 10.4° in the dehydrated structure and shifted to 10.0° upon hydration. We suppose thus that the shift of the peak after contact with air indicates that despite the breakdown of the crystalline structure after NH3 adsorption the solid preserves (at least partially) its porosity. This is indeed the case as follows from MeOH adsorption isotherm by the sample exposed to NH3 (Figure S7). Even if the maximum amount adsorbed is lower than for the pristine solid (0.05 instead of 0.09 g/g) the isotherm confirms the porosity of the amorphous phase obtained after adsorption of NH3. Due to this important property [1] shows a fully reversible character of NH3 adsorption (b).

elements.content: In this work we report on the preparation and adsorption properties of a water stable and highly hydrophilic porous coordination polymer based on viologen-carboxylate type ligand, 4,4′-bipyridinium-1,1′bis­(2-carboxyphenyl) (pc2), obtained by solvothermal method: [Cd3(pc2) (BTC)2(H2O)2]·6H2O (BTC3– = 1,3,5-carboxy-benzene) ([1(H2O)2]·6H2O). It is found that dehydration of [1(H2O)2]·6H2O provokes structural transitions in which the crystallinity of the sample is retained. The crystalline structure was determined for the fully hydrated compound as well as for two intermediate phases: [1]·2H2O and [1(H2O)]·3H2O. Localization of water molecules and structure of Cd trinuclear building unit are related and shown to be dependent on water content. In [1]·2H2O both water molecules are localized in the pores and the [Cd3(CO2)8] cluster has a symmetrical structure. In contrast, in [1(H2O)]·3H2O one molecule is coordinated to Cd leading to formation of an asymmetrical unit [Cd3(CO2)8(H2O)]. The fully hydrated phase ([1(H2O)2]·6H2O) contains two coordinated molecules and a symmetrical cluster [Cd3(CO2)8(H2O)2]. The existence of the partially hydrated phases with a well-defined water stoichiometry is confirmed by the presence of three well-resolved steps in the water adsorption isotherm of 1. Also, the uptake of 50% of water at P/P S < 0.01 shows the highly hydrophilic nature of dehydrated 1. The prepared PCP exhibits a high affinity toward another polar molecule, NH3, achieving at 930 hPa the uptake as high as 0.3 g/g (or 17.6 mmol/g). It is worth noting that this capacity is entirely preserved after regeneration under vacuum at 180 °C despite formation of an amorphous phase after NH3 adsorption.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this work we report on the preparation and adsorption properties of a water stable and highly hydrophilic porous coordination polymer based on viologen-carboxylate type ligand, 4,4'-bipyridinium-1,1'bis(2-carboxyphenyl) (pc2), obtained by solvothermal method: [Cd3(pc2) (BTC)2(H2O)2]⋅6H2O (BTC3- = 1,3,5-carboxy-benzene) ([1(H2O)2]⋅6H2O). It is found that dehydration of [1(H2O)2]⋅6H2O provokes structural transitions in which the crystallinity of the sample is retained. The crystalline structure was determined for the fully hydrated compound as well as for two intermediate phases: [1]⋅2H2O and [1(H2O)]⋅3H2O. Localization of water molecules and structure of Cd trinuclear building unit are related and shown to be dependent on water content. In [1]⋅2H2O both water molecules are localized in the pores and the [Cd3(CO2)8] cluster has a symmetrical structure. In contrast, in [1(H2O)]⋅3H2O one molecule is coordinated to Cd leading to formation of an asymmetrical unit [Cd3(CO2)8(H2O)]. The fully hydrated phase ([1(H2O)2]⋅6H2O) contains two coordinated molecules and a symmetrical cluster [Cd3(CO2)8(H2O)2]. The existence of the partially hydrated phases with a well-defined water stoichiometry is confirmed by the presence of three well-resolved steps in the water adsorption isotherm of 1. Also, the uptake of 50% of water at P/P S < 0.01 shows the highly hydrophilic nature of dehydrated 1. The prepared PCP exhibits a high affinity toward another polar molecule, NH3, achieving at 930 hPa the uptake as high as 0.3 g/g (or 17.6 mmol/g). It is worth noting that this capacity is entirely preserved after regeneration under vacuum at 180 °C despite formation of an amorphous phase after NH3 adsorption.

cln_elements.content: A mixture of (H2pc2)­Cl2·2H2O (25.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), Cd­(ClO4)2 hydrate (62.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), DMF (2 mL), and H2O (2 mL) was slowly heated to 105 °C at a rate of 10 °C/h for 48 h in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. After the mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/h, suitable crystals for X-ray analyses were collected, washed with fresh DMF, and air-dried. [Cd3(pc2) (BTC)2(H2O)2]·6H2O 60% yield based on (H2pc2)­Cl2·2H2O. Anal. Calc. for Cd3C42H38O24N2 (1291.97): C, 39.05%; H, 2.94%; N, 2.17%. Found: C, 39.15%; H, 2.87%; N, 2.18%.

Preparation of [Cd3(pc2) (BTC)2(H2O)2]⋅6H2O

A mixture of (H2pc2)Cl2⋅2H2O (25.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), Cd(ClO4)2 hydrate (62.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), DMF (2 mL), and H2O (2 mL) was slowly heated to 105 °C at a rate of 10 °C/h for 48 h in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. After the mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/h, suitable crystals for X-ray analyses were collected, washed with fresh DMF, and air-dried. [Cd3(pc2) (BTC)2(H2O)2]⋅6H2O 60% yield based on (H2pc2)Cl2⋅2H2O. Anal. Calc. for Cd3C42H38O24N2 (1291.97): C, 39.05%; H, 2.94%; N, 2.17%. Found: C, 39.15%; H, 2.87%; N, 2.18%.

cln_elements.content:
A water stable and highly hydrophilic porous coordination polymer based on viologen-carboxylate type ligand, the 4,4′-bipyridinium,1,1-bis­(3-carboxyphenyl) (pc2), is obtained by the solvothermal method: [Cd3(pc2) (BTC)2(H2O)2]·6H2O ([1(H2O)2]·6H2O; BTC3– = 1,3,5-carboxybenzene). Its crystal structure and the ones of two partially dehydrated phases have been determined, allowing insight into the mechanism of water adsorption/desorption of this PCP material. It is shown that the dehydrated compound [1] first adsorbs two water molecules which fill the pores, leading to [1]·2H2O. On the other hand, the partial dehydration of the as-synthesized compound leads to the intermediate phase [1(H2O)]·3H2O in which one H2O molecule is bound to Cd2+ ions of trinuclear building units, and three others are localized in the pores. The structural analysis also reveals that the pyridinium N+ Lewis sites, which interact with water molecules in [1(H2O)2]·6H2O, interact with carboxylate groups after structural reorganization in [1]·2H2O. The water adsorption isotherm clearly shows that the dehydrated compound is highly hydrophilic and adsorbs water in three steps: first and second at P/P S < 0.01 and third at P/P S ∼ 0.1 with the overall water adsorption reaching 0.13 g H2O/g. This material is also able to reversibly adsorb ammonia (up to 0.3 g/g or 17.6 mmol/g).

Here, we report on the synthesis and adsorption properties of a water stable 3D PCP based on the pc2 viologen-caboxylate ligand (pc2 = 4,4′-bipyridinium-1,1-bis­(3-carboxyphenyl), ), [Cd3(pc2) (BTC)2(H2O)2]·6H2O ([1(H2O)2]·6H2O) (BTC3– = 1,3,5-carboxy-benzene). Its crystal structure, as well as that of two partially dehydrated phases [1(H2O)]·3H2O and [1]·2H2O, has been determined allowing a detailed description of the structural transitions provoked by water desorption and adsorption processes. We show that a high resolution water adsorption isotherm confirms this three-step adsorption process. It clearly shows the highly hydrophilic nature of the compound: 50% of water molecules being adsorbed at P/P S < 0.01, which can be related to the presence of Lewis acid sites in the structure (metal open sites and pyridinium cycles). In addition, the prepared PCP possesses high capacity toward NH3 attaining the loading of 0.3 g/g (17.6 mmol/g) at 930 hPa. Despite the collapse of the crystalline structure after NH3 adsorption, the solid capacity for ammonia is restored after regeneration.

Results and DiscussionThermal Behavior and Crystal Structures

The solvothermal reaction of (H2pc2)­Cl2 2H2O, cadmium perchlorate, and H3BTC led to the pure phase of a new viologen-carboxylate PCP whose formulation, first revealed from the crystal structure determination, is [Cd3(pc2) (BTC)2(H2O)2]·6H2O named [1(H2O)2]·6H2O. The thermogravimetric analysis first confirms the amount of 8 water molecules per formulation unit as the weight loss of 11.24% corresponds to the theoretical one of 11.15%. It also shows that the dehydrated compound is stable up to 350 °C, and that the water weight loss occurs in two consecutive equivalent steps of 5.65% and 5.59%, which can be assigned to the departure of 4 first water molecules following by the departure of the 4 others (). The measurement of XRPD patterns at different temperatures (thermodiffractometry) under N2 atmosphere which have been carried out in the RT–145 °C range (RT: room temperature, Figure S2) clearly shows two main phase transformations: a first change in the peak positions occurs at 35 °C giving a partially dehydrated phase which is stable up to 65 °C, while the second phase transition occurs at 85 °C giving the expected fully dehydrated phase, in accordance with the TGA analysis. We also notice another change of several peak positions at 115 °C revealing a slight change of unit cell parameters of the dehydrated phase.

CH<sub>3</sub>OH, H<sub>2</sub>O, and NH<sub>3</sub> Adsorption Measurements

The presence of permanent porosity in fully dehydrated [1] is confirmed by the adsorption of methanol at 298 K (Figure S7). The shape of the isotherm is characteristic of a microporous solid and the maximum adsorbed amount of methanol (0.09 g/g) corresponds to pore volume of 0.11 cm3/g. The isotherm of water adsorption on dehydrated [1] compound is presented in . The saturation uptake is close to eight molecules of water per formula unit in accordance with TGA and structure determination, corresponding to an adsorption of 0.13 g.g–1. The step in the isotherm occurring at four H2O molecules is attributed to the formation of the intermediate phase containing this number of water molecules. This step in the adsorption isotherm and a slight hysteresis are indicative of a structural rearrangement during the transition between the phase containing four H2O molecules and the fully hydrated one. Another important feature of the isotherm is a strong adsorption at a very low water pressure: the solid adsorbs a half the water below 0.01 of saturated water pressure, and nearly all the water molecules at P/P S = 0.1. Such behavior reveals a strong hydrophilic character of [1] in comparison with most of the known MOFs as reported in two recent reviews on water adsorption in MOFs. Finally, the log scale drawing of the water adsorption isotherm (, right) allows one to distinguish for the first adsorption step (four water molecules) two substeps of two water molecules each, the first substep corresponding to extremely low water pressure (P/P S < 0.001). It is also worth noting that the crystal structure of the phase we expected to be fully dehydrated has revealed the presence of two water molecules per formula unit. In addition to its strong hydrophilic character, [1] shows a remarkable stability toward water. It preserves a constant water capacity in multiple cycles of water adsorption (Figure S8). Also, its structure is fully preserved after immersion in liquid water as attested by XRPD (Figure S3).

[1] adsorbs a significant amount of ammonia attaining 0.3 g/g or 17.6 mmol/g at 930 hPa (a). This important uptake is due to chemisorption of NH3 which interacts with Cd2+ cations and forms the [Cd­(NH3)6]2+ complex similarly to another Cd-based PCP described in our previous work. Giving Cd content in the anhydrous material (2.6 mmol/g), this adsorption mechanism could provide the capacity of 15.6 mmol­(NH3)/g. Such chemisorption should naturally result in degradation of the crystalline structure of the material, which indeed happens in [1] saturated with ammonia as confirmed by in situ XRPD (c). It should be noted, however, that degassing the sample at 298 K results in the appearance of a peak at ∼9.5° in the diffraction pattern indicative of the existence of a partial crystalline order in the degassed sample. Moreover, upon contact with air the peak shifts to ∼9.2° reflecting the swelling of the partially ordered structure upon insertion of water molecules. Even if the attribution of this peak to any crystalline plane is impossible, this behavior is similar to that of the (110) peak located at 10.4° in the dehydrated structure and shifted to 10.0° upon hydration. We suppose thus that the shift of the peak after contact with air indicates that despite the breakdown of the crystalline structure after NH3 adsorption the solid preserves (at least partially) its porosity. This is indeed the case as follows from MeOH adsorption isotherm by the sample exposed to NH3 (Figure S7). Even if the maximum amount adsorbed is lower than for the pristine solid (0.05 instead of 0.09 g/g) the isotherm confirms the porosity of the amorphous phase obtained after adsorption of NH3. Due to this important property [1] shows a fully reversible character of NH3 adsorption (b).
